review.title: Scalable Parallel Numerical CSP Solver
review.abstract: We present a parallel solver for numerical constraint satisfaction problems (NCSPs) that can scale on a number of cores. Our proposed method runs worker solvers on the available cores and simultaneously the workers cooperate for the search space distribution and balancing. In the experiments, we attained up to 119-fold speedup using 256 cores of a parallel computer.

sections.heading: 3 Parallel Branch and Prune
sections.text: We propose a parallel method that identifies multiple workers on the available CPU cores p0,.., p # p − 1 (we assume that a single worker runs on a core and identifies both a worker and a core with pi).The workers in the queue interleave the following three procedures and cooperate in a decentralized manner: (i) breadth-first branch and prune search, (ii) distribution and workload balance of search space in a sender-initiated manner, and (iii) termination detection. Sub-trees in the search space of the branch and prune is unbalanced but can be independant: there is no confluence of multiple branches, and we have no shared information between branches. Distribution of the search space among workers is done in preprocess and postprocess as described in the following subsections. The pre-process distributes the parts of the search space to the other workers, and the post-process balances the burden of each worker during the search.

sections.heading: 4.1 Discussions
sections.text: In the experiments, our method scaled up to 256 cores with the optimal configurations. We achieved accelerations up to 32.3 times using 40 cores of the common storage machine and up to 119 times using 256 cores of the cluster machine.However, the best acceleration of 119 times was achieved with the process. The process facilitated and accelerated the distribution of workload in the early stages of the search process. This was because the load balancing process was too infrequent for the specified number of workers and the workload diffusion became too slow when many cores were used (e.g., sp2-4 with ns = 1000 and the experiments on the cluster).This was because the load balancing process was too low for the specified number of workers and the labor force diffusion became too slow. When comparing the right graphs for the instance sp2-4, ns = 1000, in Figure 4, we can find that the point of saturation shifts to the size of the search engine.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a parallel branch and prune algorithm based on a non-portfolio approach to the division of search space. In the experiments, using 256 X10 locations (i.e. cores), we achieved acceleration factors of up to 119. We expect our parallel solver to be applied to major practical problems, such as robotics problems in [3].Recognition. This work was partly funded by JSPS (KAKENHI 25880008 and 25700038).
